page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY:SWANSEA WEST
page.content: Many years ago, Killay was known as Goetre, which means "pasture land". Along the high ground above Clyne Valley were very old farms which gave their names to the village:Goetre Fawr,Goetre Fach and Goetre Bellaf. Where shops,houses and pubs are now were fields,woods and streams and only a few scattered houses, which were probably small-holdings.Lower Killay came into being with the construction of the London & North Western Railway in the mid-19th century. In 1877 a school was built for the children of Dunvant village and the few who lived in Killay.People moved into the district because of the brickworks and coalmines, the last of the latter closing between the wars. Since then, the area has developed as a suburb of Swansea.
